case_name: Petitions Nos. 12, 13 and 14 of 1951 and Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 14, 15 and 16

facts.text: Military Governor of Hyderabad enacted the Special Tribunals Regulation No. 5 of 1358 F on 30th October 1948

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th October, 1948, the Military Governor of Hyderabad by virtue of the powers delegated to him by E.H. the Nizam enacted the Special Tribunals Regulation  No. 5 of 1358 F ,

facts.text: Regulation amended by later Regulations on 22nd May 1949, 10th July 1949, 23rd July 1949 and 30th October 1949

anchor.surface_text: which was amended by several later Regu- lations issued on the 22nd May, 1949, 10th July, 1949, 23rd July and 30th October, 1949.

facts.text: Military Governor constituted Special Tribunal A for Nalgonda district

anchor.surface_text: In accord- ance with the Regulation, certain Tribunals were companystitut- ed, and one of the Tribunals--Tribunal A for Nalgonda dis- trict--

facts.text: Civil Administrator of Nalgonda made over cases to Tribunal A including Criminal Cases Nos. 14, 17 and 18 of 1949

anchor.surface_text: proceeded to try certain cases made over to it by the Civil Administrator of Nalgonda under the powers vested in him by the Military Governor. Among the cases tried by this Tribunal were also three cases

facts.text: Charge sheet No. 14 dated 7th April 1949 submitted by Mr. Hanumantha Naidu

anchor.surface_text: these being registered as Criminal Cases Nos. 14, 17 and 18 of 1949. These cases were based on three charge sheets submitted by one Mr. Hanumantha Naidu, a senior police officer of Nalgonda district, one of which was No. 14 dated the 7th April, 1949,

facts.text: Charge sheets Nos. 14 and 15 dated 20th July 1949 submitted by Mr. Hanumantha Naidu

anchor.surface_text: and the other two were Nos. 14 and 15 dated the 20th July, 1949.

facts.text: In Criminal Case No. 14 of 1949, accused went to a village in Nalgonda on 21st September 1948 in khaki uniform with unnotified firearms, caught four persons who had not paid subscription, decoyed and killed them by cutting throats

anchor.surface_text: In the first case  Criminal Case No. 14 of 1949 , the chargesheet stated that the accused went to a certain village in Nalgonda district on 21st September, 1948 in khaki uniform and holding unnotified firearms, caught hold of four persons as they had number paid the full subscrip- tion demanded of them, decoyed them to the outskirts of the village and then killed them by cutting their throats.

facts.text: In Criminal Case No. 17 of 1949, on 6th April 1949 at 9 AM two accused came to village, fired guns, ran away, later all accused marched on villagers, opened fire, one villager died from thigh injury, another minor hand injury

anchor.surface_text: In the second case  Criminal Case No. 17 , it was stated that on the 6th April, 1949, at about 9 A.M. two of the accused came to a certain village and began to fire their guns, but when the public approached them asking them to surrender they ran away and joined the other persons accused in the case. Later on, all the accused marched on the villagers and opened fire at them indiscriminately with the result that one of them received an injury in his right high which subsequently proved fatal, and another received a minor injury on his left hand.

facts.text: Alternative version in Case 17: two accused chased by 50-100 persons to Madireddychelka, other accused joined, accused No.4 fired hitting villager on thigh who died, then chased others, one bullet grazed finger

anchor.surface_text: The version given at the trial in this case was slightly different and shows that the two accused who had visited the village were chased by 50 or 100 persons to a place called Madireddychelka where the other accused joined them, and after parleying with the chasers, accused No. 4 fired and hit one of the villagers on the thigh and the latter died. Thereupon the accused chased the remaining villagers, firing their guns, and one of the bullets grazed the middle finger of one of the villagers and caused a slight injury to it.

facts.text: In Criminal Case No. 18 of 1949, on 15th May midnight accused visited Kasthala village in khaki with firearms, caught Natala Rama Reddy from terrace, took to outskirts despite protests, killed by gunshots

anchor.surface_text: In the third case  Criminal Case No. 18 , the facts were stated to be these--On the 15th May, at about midnight, the accused visited Kasthala village, carrying firearms and dressed in khaki uniform. They got upon the terrace of one Kankayya where one Natala Rama Reddy was sleeping, caught hold of him and took him forcibly to the outskirts of the village in spite of the protests of a number of villagers who had followed, and killed him by firing gunshots at him.

facts.text: Petitioners convicted of murder and sentenced to death by Special Tribunal, also convicted of other offences including carrying firearms without licences

anchor.surface_text: Upon these facts, the trial of the petitioners proceed- ed, and they were ultimately companyvicted of murder and sen- tenced to death, and also companyvicted of certain other of- fences including the offence of carrying firearms without licences

facts.text: Petitioners appealed to Hyderabad High Court, convictions and sentences confirmed

anchor.surface_text: After their companyviction, the petitioners appealed to the Hyderabad High Court, but their companyvictions and sentences were companyfirmed.

facts.text: High Court judgment and order dated 19th December 1950 by M. Khaliluzzaman Siddiqi J.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment and order dated 19th December, 1950, of the High Court of Judi- cature at Hyderabad  M. Khaliluzzaman Siddiqi J.  in Miscel-. laneous Petitions Nos. 2297, 2298 and 2299 of 1950.

facts.text: Petitioners applied for leave to appeal to Judicial Committee of Hyderabad, applications pending when Constitution of India came into force

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, they tried to obtain the leave of the High Court for appealing to the Judicial Committee of Hyderabad, but, while their applications were still pending, the Constitution of India came into force

facts.text: Special leave to appeal to Supreme Court dismissed on ground no jurisdiction for pre-26 Jan 1950 Hyderabad High Court judgments

anchor.surface_text: they applied to this Court for special leave to appeal, but that application was dismissed on the ground that this Court had numberjurisdiction under article 136 of the Constitution to hear an appeal from a judgment delivered by the High Court at Hyderabad before the 26th January, 1950,

facts.text: Petitioners filed petitions under Art 32 (Nos.12,13,14 of 1951) and under Art 136 (Criminal Misc Petitions 14,15,16)

anchor.surface_text: These were two sets of petitions by three groups of persons, one under Art. 32 of the Consti- tution  Petitions Nos. 12, 13 and 14, of 1951  and the other under Art. 136 1  of the Constitution  Criminal Miscellane- ous Petitions Nos. 14, 15 and 16

facts.text: In Cases 17 and 18, accused not afforded opportunity to instruct counsel, remained undefended

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Cases Nos. 17 and 18 of 1949, there was numberfair trial, inasmuch as the persons accused in Vide 1950 S.C.R. 940. those eases were number afforded any opportunity to instruct companynsel and they had remained undefended throughout the trial.

anchor.surface_text: The general ground urged to make good this point is that the order made by the Civil Administrator purporting to companyfer jurisdiction on the Special Tribunal to try the petitioners did number indicate with sufficient certainty that the petitioners were the persons whose cases were to be tried by that Tribunal,

facts.text: Accused in Case 17 brought to court on 3 Aug 1949, informed case on 6 Aug, must get lawyers and witnesses

anchor.surface_text: Further a reference to the docket sheets in Case No. 17 shows that the accused in Case No. 17 were brought into companyrt on the 3rd August, 1949, and they were informed on that day that the case would be heard on the 6th August, 1949, and that they must get ready with their defence law- yers and witnesses on that date.

facts.text: Trial in Case 17 concluded on 14 Aug 1949, Case 18 on 13 Aug 1949

anchor.surface_text: The docket sheets also show that the trial was companycluded in Case No. 17 on the 14th August and in Case No. 18 on the 13th August.

issues.text: Whether the trial of the petitioners by the Special Tribunal was without jurisdiction?

anchor.surface_text: The trial of the petitioners by the Special Tribu- nal was without jurisdiction. In Criminal Cases Nos. 17 and 18 of 1949, there was nofair trial, inasmuch as the persons accused in Vide 1950 S.C.R. 940.

issues.text: Whether there was a fair trial in Criminal Cases Nos. 17 and 18 of 1949 due to lack of opportunity to instruct counsel and remaining undefended?

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Cases Nos. 17 and 18 of 1949, there was nofair trial, inasmuch as the persons accused in Vide 1950 S.C.R. 940. those eases were not afforded any opportunity to instruct counsel and they had remained undefended throughout the trial.

issues.text: Whether the trials were illegal by reason of misjoinder of charges?

anchor.surface_text: The trials in question were illegal by reason of misjoinder of charges.

issues.text: Whether the sentence of death could be lawfully executed by hanging or only by decapitation?

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the passing of the sentence, the sentence of death could be lawfully executed by decapitation only and not by hanging, and hence the sentence of death by hanging passed upon the accused in the first case was illegal.

issues.text: Whether the sentence of death could be executed without the assent or approval of H.E.H. the Nizam?

anchor.surface_text: The sentence of death could not be executed without the assent or the lapproval of H.E.H. the Nizam which had not yet been obtained.

issues.text: Whether the Supreme Court can grant relief under Article 32 including writs of habeas corpus, certiorari or prohibition after appellate confirmation of conviction?

anchor.surface_text: Article 32 2 provides that the Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, that this Court may issue a writ in the nature of certiorari or a direction or order directed to respondents writ of prohibition or a direction or order directed to respondents Nos. 1 and 2

issues.text: Whether principles of finality of judgments prevent collateral attack via Article 32 on convictions affirmed by appellate court even on jurisdiction grounds?

anchor.surface_text: there is such a principle as finality of judgments, which applies to criminal as well as civil cases

arguments.claim: Habeas corpus cannot go behind conviction affirmed on appeal even on jurisdiction grounds

anchor.surface_text: There is a long line of cases relating to the habeas companypus writs, in which it has been held that when the return states that the party who is alleged to be unlaw- fully detained, is detained in execution of a sentence on indictment on a criminal charge, the return cannot be company- troverted.

arguments.claim: Amended Regulation has retrospective effect on mode of execution

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, they must be taken to have retrospective effect, because the mode of the execution of a sentence can hardly be regarded as a matter of substantive law

arguments.claim: Section 271 Hyderabad CrPC gives right to pleader but no vitiation if unrepresented unless fair trial negated

anchor.surface_text: The provision which is material to the companytention raised before us is section 271 of the Hyderabad Criminal Procedure Code... Any person accused of an offence before a criminal companyrt... may of right be defended by a pleader.

arguments.claim: Distinction between lack of jurisdiction and irregular exercise; latter curable on appeal

anchor.surface_text: There is a basic difference between want of jurisdiction and an illegal or irregular exercise of jurisdiction...

arguments.claim: Subramania Iyer distinguished; misjoinder effect modified by later Privy Council cases

anchor.surface_text: The entire argument on behalf of the petitioners was based on the case of Subramania lyer v. King Emperor... The case has been discussed, ex- plained and distinguished in a number of cases...

arguments.claim: Pre-Constitution High Court not inferior court for certiorari/prohibition

anchor.surface_text: The writs of certiorari and prohibi- tion are hardly appropriate remedies in this case, because they are usually directed to an inferior companyrt, but at the date when the High Court dealt with these cases...

holdings.text: Even assuming misjoinder of charges, it does not mean the trial court acted without jurisdiction; distinction between lack of jurisdiction and irregular exercise, latter curable on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: But, for the purpose of the present case, it is sufficient to point out that even if we assume that there was some defect in the procedure followed at the trial, it does number follow that the trial court acted without jurisdiction. There is a basic difference between want of jurisdiction and an illegal or irregular exercise of jurisdiction,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Subramania Iyer; follows later Privy Council cases modifying broad rule; jurisdiction vs irregular exercise; affirmed on appeal.

holdings.text: Amended Special Tribunals Regulation providing for hanging has retrospective effect as mode of execution is procedural, not substantive.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, they must be taken to have retrospective effect, because the mode of the execution of a sentence can hardly be regarded as a matter of substantive law or something which would affect any substantive rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hyderabad Penal Code s.243 and CrPC s.311 silent on mode; amendment post-sentence but pre-confirmation applies to unexecuted sentences; High Court power under amendment.

holdings.text: Tausiq by Military Governor under Regulation substitutes manzuri/assent of Nizam; no personal approval by Nizam required.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended by the learned Attorney-General that these provisions companyer all those cases where manzuri and tashih were companytemplated under the old law... the new word, tausiq, which has been used in the Regulation, and which literally means companyfirmation, appears to companyvey the same sense as the word manzuri.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets manzuri as confirmation, not personal royal sanction; used for courts/govt too; Regulations simplify procedure; hakim broad term.

holdings.text: No legal rule vitiates trial for lack of counsel unless it amounts to negation of fair trial; accused informed but chose not to engage.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.271 gives right but liberal construction; no mandatory assignment unless incapable; facts show opportunity given, means available, declined even in appeal.

holdings.text: Reference to charge sheet numbers in transfer orders by Civil Administrator sufficient to confer jurisdiction on Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court in negativing it relied on the orders made by the Civil Administrator in two letters produced before it, viz.,  1  letter No. 3176/49-ST, dated 7th April, 1949, by which criminal cases companyered by charge sheets Nos. 1 to 14

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge sheets contain names/details; particularizes cases; High Court relied on letters.

holdings.text: Supreme Court cannot grant habeas corpus, certiorari or prohibition under Art 32 to challenge convictions affirmed by pre-Constitution High Court on jurisdiction grounds due to finality of judgments.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows English precedents (Newton, etc.); appellate court competent even if wrong on jurisdiction; s.355 Hyderabad CrPC finality; cannot go behind return showing detention under sentence.

holdings.text: Principle of finality of judgments prevents collateral attack via Art 32 on affirmed convictions, even if trial court lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: there is such a principle as finality of judgments, which applies to criminal as well as civil cases and is implicit in every system, wherein provisions are to be found for companyrecting errors in appeal or in revision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies to criminal cases; High Court judgment final pre-Constitution; Constitution not retrospective; indirect appeal not allowed.
